dialogues.speaker: CASTLE
dialogues.text: Now comes the moon riding over the horizon. Upon a hill a the edge of the wood squats a castle, its crude stonework bathed in cold silvery light. Queer carvings and runes  decorate the ponderous gate. Heavy vines are climbing up walls. The castle is old, its unfamiliar form testament t an ancient mind and an ancient craft. Flickering candle l dances on a leaded windowpane. Inside, the corridors are dark and silent. Under low arch ceilings the uneven floors are paved with stone blocks.  Perched over lintels and crouched in niches are icons wit strange animal heads.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: A sleep on a straw palette in a room strewn with vegetabl and crockery is Hodge, a wrinkled old retainer. A flicker candle and empty jug are beside the bed. He is snoring ge

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: This circular chamber at the heart of the castle is stuff with parchments, scrolls, dusty books, bronze braziers, g retorts, chemical salts, birds both stuffed and caged. An iron candelabra stands on a work table, tapers burning. I the soft glow it seems that the room is unoccupied, but n moving in the background is a shadowy figure, preparing f a magical deed. Feet are positioned carefully within a  pentagram chiseled into the floor. A scroll is consulted; comes an arm and a voice blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in  Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia  nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, candles, out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the little flames stand at attention without so much a tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi:  Lux! Exstinguat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no use. There is a sigh and the figure moves forward into the light. Revealed in the glow is the discouraged f of Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: TOWER
dialogues.text: Carrying the candelabra, the youth trudges up a circular  staircase.

dialogues.speaker: TURRET
dialogues.text: The highest point of the castle is a turret, open to the  stars and the night air. Here, more magic is afoot. An ol enchanter, Ulrich, Magister Ipsissimus, pours water from silver ewer into a stone bowl. As the surface ripples  disappear he leans forward and gazes into the pool. All a once his face hardens as the distant sounds of screams an thunder reach his ears. Lights and shadows, reflected fro within the basin, play across his face. His frown deepens the sound of his own voice comes to him from the vision i the water -- Draco draconis -- suddenly squelched by the  roar of flame and an ugly snarl. At that moment Galen reaches the top of the steps and hol up the candelabra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vide, Magister. There's something  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulrich, startled from his trance, slaps the water out of basin and turns to confront his student. Galen is taken a by the old man's grim countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just seen something. Something  of consequence to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm) Yes. My own death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a distracted gesture he causes the flames to extingu themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we had better hasten your  training.

dialogues.speaker: BARNYARD
dialogues.text: Outside the castle wall Hodge is feeding the chickens and ducks. He straightens up and squints through the early mo mists. On a distant hillock two figures are moving toward the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH AND GALEN
dialogues.text: Hobbling slowly with the aid of a pair of canes, Ulrich g his pupil across a wooden bridge and along a stream into forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stern and troubled) This wood, these leaves, the birds,  the very dome of heaven, once they  all rang with one great chord: and  philosophers like me kept it all in  tune. Now, new voices are singing  new songs. (sharply) Have you mastered the threefold  transmutation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very difficult. Have you  committed to memory undying the Codex  de Profundis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shrug) The first two chapters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's long. And what about the Ritual  of Banishment as prescribed by my  late master Balisarius?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell the truth, I haven't dared  try it. What's the point, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point? The point is you don't  know it, and you're no magician  without it. It was my hope to school  you, to mold your faculties and  wits... I still believe you have  some talent. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate books. I hate drill. I want a  real task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time now. When I'm gone,  half the powers in the universe will  vanish with me. And what's the use  of a few lingering skills if they're  left in the hands of a child? (pause) Listen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulrich gauges the young man standing before him and makes decision. Reaching under his cloak he lifts off a fine si chain with an amulet dangling from it. He drapes it aroun Galen's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, wear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen instinctively wraps his hand around the jewel. He c an ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voices, singing on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hastens forward to a promontory, eager to have a look. Ulrich does not follow. Instead, doffing his cloak, he wh it before him, where it magically floats a few feet off t ground. Awkwardly, the old man clambers aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back, but the wizard is gone. A shadow falls ove him. He looks up. There, two hundred feet above the tree  tops his master is soaring on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: AIRBORNE
dialogues.text: The old conjurer squints into the distance. Miles away an far below a company of drab walkers winds along the margi of the forest. They are singing a mournful round.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and  addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shout) We have visitors!

dialogues.speaker: ROTUNDA
dialogues.text: Clustering together in the center of a wide reception hal is a contingent of weary peasants, awkward amidst the dus rugs, drapes and heavy furniture. Their leader is a fineb youth, not yet twenty. Like the others, he is uneasy; his name is Valerian. Hodge enters and sets a tray of mead be them. He leaves without a word. The visitors stare glumly the refreshment, but are too timorous to go near it.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen helps Ulrich prepare for the audience. The sorcerer peers at himself in a full-length mirror, adjusting the h of a black robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks forbidding enough, don't you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are your sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- they'll think me infirm. You  know, Balisarius wore this whenever  he changed lead into gold. He could  really do that, you know. I never  could. Too bad -- you'd stand to  inherit some real wealth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a morbid frame of mind.  What's all this about dying? You  don't even look sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tying on a sash) You still wearing that amulet? (Galen nods) Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs away from the mirror and fits a silver coronet o his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a  handful of that sulphurous ash over  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sorcerer starts down a circular stone staircase.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROTUNDA
dialogues.text: The visitors watch warily as a door swings open and Galen makes his entrance, his face expressionless and hands pre together. He looks rather young to be the famous Ulrich. Galen allows a moment to go by, then throws his arms wide Ka-whump! and Ulrich appears in the doorway in a smoky  fireball. Alarmed, the visitors retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunc habeus lux!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pffst! around the room candles flare in their niches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Et calor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the fireplace, the birch logs are suddenly ablaze. Ulr totters to the hearth and extends long bony fingers towar the warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich.  Which one of you calls himself  Valerian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The travelers are suitably dazzled by the magician's  performance. The young leader of the party screws up his  courage and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be me. We are here on  behalf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you're here. You're a  delegation from Urland, from beyond  Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The travelers exchange nervous glances. Valerian motions one of his companions. The man steps forward and hands ov a leather pouch. One by one, Valerian places the contents the table for Ulrich's inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. (pause) Scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this, Ulrich advances and closely examines three shimm irridescent disks as big as saucers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. How did you come by these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) I found them. At the mouth of the  lair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerian reaches under his jerkin and withdraws what appe to be a curved sword. He jabs it into the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the  gods!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs a finger along a serrated edge and gazes bleakly his visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want me to do battle with  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerian has lost all trace of timidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else can we turn to? We all know  what we're dealing with here. This  is a basilicok. (he takes a step  forward) A cockatrice. (another step, bolder) A dragon. (he leans close to  Ulrich) This is no stag, no bear, no natural  creature. This is one of your kind.  And only a necromancer such as  yourself can rid us of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you try the Meredydd sisters?  What about Rinbod? I've heard it  said he killed a dragon once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all dead. You're the only  one left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sigh, Ulrich lowers himself into a chair. He rubs withered legs and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long way to Urland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every quarter, upon the solstices  and the equinoxes there's a new  victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greil, a grizzled peasant, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter, for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister... cousins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen  by lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen edges over to the table and inspects the scales and tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master, don't you think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He broods for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of dragons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Sorcerers and dragons go back a  long long time together. If it weren't  for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any  dragons. (pause) All right. I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The travelers are making ready for departure in the grey  light of dawn. As Hodge stuffs provisions into a wicker b Ulrich wraps padding on a newly fashioned pair of crutche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know of this dragon. Vermithrax  Pejorative: she's four hundred years  old. As far as I can tell she's the  last of her kind. Very appropriate  that I'm the one to finish her off,  don't you think? (he tries out the  crutches) There. Flatten the highest mountain.  What say you, Galen? (no answer) Speak up. (still no answer) You, Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge mutters something inaudible and grimly keeps packin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Galen) While I'm gone see you keep your  nose in your books and your hands  out of my reagents. Leave my  instruments alone too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen crouches against the castle wall; he regards his ma sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at yourself. How far will you  get like that? A league, two leagues?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Why don't you wave your hands around  and summon up a coach-and-four?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mock me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen gets up and calls out to the Urlanders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pilgrims: You're used to  lotteries. Why not draw straws to  see who'll be first to carry  ironshanks here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too much for Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue. If the master's  got a mind to go, he'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen approaches the old sorcerer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send me. You're always saying I need  seasoning. I need a test. Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wan smile) Don't be so hasty. Your time will  come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walkers are ready to set forth. Hodge picks up his pa steps forward and pulls open the great gate.

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMEN
dialogues.text: Three mounted men are outside the gate, helmets on their  heads, swords on the belts and longbows across their  shoulders. They look formidable. The Urlanders take a ste backward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian is a lean, heavily bearded nobleman. There is a co of arms on the shield strapped to the pommel of his saddl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amiable) Good morning, all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not afraid of you. Give us the  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the road is yours. All the way  to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't  it? But when you're in search of a  sorcerer, I suppose no distance is  too great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing trouble, Galen moves forward. Ulrich touches his  arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen hears the urgency in the old man's voice and obeys. Hodge takes it upon himself to deal with the strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, like my good friends here,  I've come for a bit of black magic.  No doubt you've heard of our troubles  at home. This is Cragganmore, is it  not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, this be the place of Ulrich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian dismounts and saunters up to the old magician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here we have the mystical presence  himself, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd best keep your distance -- and  your manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's ready to lay a dragon in its  grave, he's got nothing to fear from  me. (turns to the Urlanders) I've no more love for that creature  than you lot. Nor has the King. But,  before you stir things up, don't you  think it a good idea to see you've  got the right man for the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha -- it's a test you're looking  for. We don't do tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you don't. They never do  tests -- and not many real deeds  either. Oh, conversation with your  grandmother's shade in a darkened  room, the odd love potion or two...  but comes a doubter, well then, it's  the wrong day, the planets are not  aligned, the entrails aren't  favorable, we don't do tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got no doubts. We require no  test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're not going to get one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Ulrich finally speaks, his voice is low and  authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Galen) Go to the conjuring room. The iron  box. Fetch me the dagger within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen's eyes widen with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dagger. Be quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen dashes into the castle. Ulrich gazes almost shyly a Tyrian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall have your test.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen comes puffing up the steps, locates the iron box, a flings it open. Amidst the tawdry paraphernalia of a  professional magician is an ivory-handled dagger covered  with runic inscriptions. Galen eagerly examines it to see how the blade might twist aside or collapse into the hand but it is all too genuine. A murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Where are you, boy? I'm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen throws open a window and looks down into the courty He displays the dagger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this one, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very one. Let it fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen hesitates, then tosses it. Tumbling end over end, i arcs downward. The old conjurer calmly stretches out a ha and plucks it neatly out of the air. Galen watches as Ulr passes the weapon to Tyrian and strips back his robe expo a bony chest. Galen knows what's coming. He rushes for th door. He's only a step away when it bangs shut of its own accord. He sprints for a second exit. Whack! This door sl shut too. Locked in. Quick, back to the window and climb  down the vine... Smack! the heavy shutters seal him in.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH AND TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Ulrich takes Tyrian's arm and guides the point of the dag to his breastbone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vita regula, vita hieratica!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is filled with dread. Hodge is shaking. From the castle come the rattling of shutters and Galen's muffled  cries. A sick sarcastic smile has crept over Tyrian's lip He tenses himself to thrust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt  me.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen stops hammering and presses his face to a crack in shutter. Below he can see the participants in this grisly drama. He holds his breath. Tyrian makes a sudden movemen and buries the blade in Ulrich's chest. But the sorcerer  stands unbent, seemingly unhurt. Then, after a long momen he slowly sags forward over the dagger and the hand that  holds it. Tyrian shrinks back and allows the body to fall a heap. Very quickly he remounts. In another moment he an his companions are gone. The others are riveted in horror Hodge sinks to his knees and wails his grief. Galen turns away from the window and gazes blankly into t gloomy conjuring room. Click! The doors unlatch themselve and swing open.

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL PYRE
dialogues.text: Ulrich, principal magician and sorcerer of the western wo reposes on a hardwood pyre. His hands are folded on his c His face is peaceful. While the visitors wordlessly look Galen touches a burning brand to the kindling. At first t fire catches normally enough, but when the flames start t envelop the body they suddenly turn pale green, producing unearthly roar. The onlookers back away from the intense  heat.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen sits alone amidst the museum-like collection of mag apparatus. He stares at the amulet, considering its  significance. His reverie is interrupted by the murmur of voices below. At the window he looks down to see Hodge bi farewell to the delegation from Urland. Valerian is the l to leave. He pauses at the gate and glances up at Galen.  Then he moves on. The young student of magic sets his jaw suddenly filled with resolve. Moving through the room, he busies himself with the old m effects. He scoops up the loose books and parchments and  locks them into trunks. He drapes muslin cloths over the  alchemical devices. He sows a handful of salt over the  pentagram inscribed in the floor. Finally, he opens the c and releases the crow, the falcon, and the great horned o

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Hodge is up on the burned out funeral pyre, anxiously scr ashes and small bones into a leather pouch -- the remains Ulrich. Up behind him comes Galen, now clad in a traveler cloak, with a pack on his back and a staff in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge -- what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge quickly conceals the pouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just making my farewell, thank you  very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He quickly climbs down, picks up his pack and follows Gal out through the gate. As the door is pushed shut a huge o timber falls into place, barring the castle against the  uninvited.

dialogues.speaker: HILLTOP
dialogues.text: Galen and Hodge labor to the crest of a grassy hill and t to look back across a wide valley. There on another hillt on the far side sits Cragganmore, lit by the red rays of setting sun. Galen removes the amulet from his neck and  clutches it in his fist. Hodge is bug-eyed to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful with that! You don't know  what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his hands toward the castle and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cragganmore! Domus non i am! Silva  celet!

dialogues.speaker: CRAGGANMORE
dialogues.text: The vines on the castle walls begin to twitch and stretch magically brought to animate life. They flow upward over masonry, branching out and covering every surface, then u onto the roof. Finally only the tops of the chimneys and highest turrets stand above the green carpet. A century's growth in a matter of seconds. GALEN & HODGE On their hilltop the old retainer gives the youth a fearf look. Galen is too flushed with excitement over what he h done to notice.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST PATH
dialogues.text: Galen and Hodge trudge along an overgrown cart-track unde an arch of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we  dwell. It doesn't matter who you  are, a king in his robes, a peasant  in his rags, when your time comes,  no magic can save you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apprentice's mind is elsewhere: he's got a coin hover in mid-air above his palm, bobbing gently as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the kindest lord a man could ask  for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was  fussy about his bath. And you'd think  he could boil his own eggs with the  snap of a finger, but no, he had old  Hodge do it, of course. (snurfling) Up before five I was, mucking out  the cages, slopping the pigs, and  never once got so much as a thankyou  or a pat on the back... (through tears) I'm going to miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plucks a low-hanging leaf, waves a hand over it, and  watches it turn into a spray of daffodils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. All you care about is  the tricks and knavery. Well, you  don't pull any wool over these old  eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk  before you fill his shoes, you mark  my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Hodge, pack too  heavy? Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the pack a slap. It flies out of its harness and floats alongside them. Hodge snatches it back and clutche it tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful with that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too cold, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great coat drapes itself over Hodge's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too warm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatcoat disappears, as do the rest of his garments, leaving him in his smalls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spluttering) Stop it, I say! Out of respect for  the master!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppressing a grin, Galen mercifully waves his hand and  restores Hodge to his usual costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got as much respect for the  master as anyone, old man. But --  then again, I'm master now.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELERS' CAMP
dialogues.text: The Urlanders are gathered around a fire, sharing a meage supper. The man named Greil pokes at the stew-pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left my farm with seeds unplanted,  calves unborn, nothing but a wife to  chase down the strays, and for what?  A funeral, that's what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks up and down behind Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because some people said, find a  magician. Not just a local fellow,  an import, a good forty leagues from  home. An all-powerful necromancer.  Ha -- some necromancer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkin, an older man, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you  the Great Bear. His tail points east.  It's the equinox. Have you forgotten?  Or rather not think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserable) He's right. I brought us here for  nothing. May the gods help whoever's  daughter it is tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a noise from the darkness beyond the campfire. T of the men get to their feet and listen. At first silence then more rustling. Without a word the two men dart into bushes and haul two interlopers before the company: Galen and Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morrow, good morrow. Peace be  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now. We mean no harm. We've  been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growl) Well, you've found us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing himself off) More the other way around, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few words, that's all. You were  looking for a conjurer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Requiscat in pace. (he takes a deep breath) Ecce: magister novus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen surveys the puzzled faces. He draws himself up and  plunges in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord Ulrich is no longer. All  that you asked of him, you may now  expect of me. The dangers he would  face, I will now conquer. The task  he would undertake I will now fulfill.  I am Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of  Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and I  am the Sorcerer you seek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment of depressed silence. Hodge rolls his e Greil starts to chuckle, then to laugh. Soon the others a laughing too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a handsome thought, O  wizard of wizards. But if there's  one thing our friend Tyrian has shown  us, it's to beware the pig in the  poke. Who's got a dagger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tests!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it proof, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone brings out a dagger and hands it to Greil. Valeri pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've seen enough tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Greil persists, waving the knife at the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I haven't. All I've seen is  death. Death in our families, death  on the road, and tonight, death at  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lashes out with the knife. Galen jumps back, but Valer steps in, delivering a quick kick to Greil's gut, followe by a right to the jaw that sends the bigger man sprawling He takes the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's come over you, anyway? Have  you lost your wits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He propels Galen out of harm's way and sits him down on t other side of the fire. Greil nurses his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it. Young snot-nose  comes in here for sport at our  expense. We're on a fool's errand,  but we don't have to listen to this.  I don't want to hear any more about  sorcery. I don't want to hear any  more about spells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerian hands Galen a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) What's the matter with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just him. It's all of us.  It's the equinox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The moon shines down on the far reaches of the Kingdom of Urland, coldly lighting a barren landscape filled with th skeletons of dead trees, blackened rock and bare ground.  Advancing across this mournful terrain is a troop of arme men leading a blindfolded horse and tumbril. The horse is skittish. Finally, in spite of shouts and lashings, it re to go further. The leader, Horsrik, barks out an order:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close enough! Bring her out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman, no more than seventeen, is brought forth f the cart. Long black hair falls down over a white tunic. dark eyes dart fearfully around in her pale face. She is  half-carried, half dragged to the edge of a steaming crac in the ground where she is manacled to a wooden post. By  lantern-light, Horsrik reads from a parchment scroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now be it known throughout the  kingdom, that this maiden, having  lawfully been chosen by a deed of  fortune and destiny, shall hereby  give up her life for the greater  good of Urland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a low rumble; the earth shakes. Horsrik glances  nervously around. He carries on by rote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this act shall be satisfied the  powers that dwell underground and  the spirits that attend thereto. In  gratitude for this sacrifice His  Majesty has declared the family --  what's the name? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prods the girl, but she is too terrified to speak. Ben them, the earth seems to groan. Smoke issues from the mou of the pit. One of the nervous witnesses leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plowman! The family Plowman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing it) -- the family Plowman to be free of  obligations, taxations, levys and  imposts for a period not to exceed  five years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse suddenly rears, and blindfold notwithstanding,  gallops off, dragging the tumbril over the rocks. The men behind Horsrik break ranks and scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- ordained and signed this day,  etc., Casiodorus, in his glory the  reigning king of this our realm...  his seal, his mark, duly read by  Chancellor Horsrik in his holy name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Horsrik joins the flight, chasing his men back over t murky horizon.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL
dialogues.text: She strains against her manacles, cocking her head to lis as the rumblings below subside. Presently the steam and s blow away and she can see the horse pawing and stamping a hundred yards distant, the wheel of the cart jammed betwe rocks. Summoning up a wild will to live, she squeezes her hands against the cold iron rings. No use. She spits on h wrists and twists desperately. Blood starts. One hand sli free. She looks at the horse. The animal tosses off its  blindfold and looks back at her. Now she strains again an pulls her other hand free. She wipes the blood on her fro and sprints toward the horse. But she doesn't get there. earth abruptly shifts from under her feet, tumbling her a cracked and steaming rocks. When she raises her head a hu shadow has fallen over the horse. There is a piteous whin then a roar. The girl's face is suddenly lit by flames. S scrambles to her feet and rushes back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE
dialogues.text: The girl hasn't taken a dozen steps when something huge  hurtles forward and blocks her way. Something scaly and  glittering. She whirls and stumbles off in a new directio This time she's cut off by a monstrous claw tipped with r like talons. She screams and crawls away. Another claw  prevents her escape.

dialogues.speaker: THE CREATURE
dialogues.text: Membranous wings fold down against the night sky. Up come the silhouette of a reptilian head swaying on a serpentin neck. There's an angry hiss. A sheet of flame envelops  everything.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: Tyrian kneels beside a mountain waterfall, having a drink while his men hover in the background. One of them points down the slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. I see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian wipes his mouth unhurriedly and strolls over to lo Far below, half hidden by trees, the little company of  Urlanders winds its way through the forest. A frown creeps over Tyrian's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one. That's the man from  Cragganmore. Now what's he doing  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filling in for the chief, I reckon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary) What a pity.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Hodge marches along with the rest. When he's sure no one  else is looking he burrows into his garments and brings o the leather pouch containing Ulrich's ashes. Reassured th it's still with him, he tucks it away again. Galen falls  into step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little gold, eh? What do you say I  change it into lead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your jokes for someone else.  Me, I don't care for braggarts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass Valerian, who has dropped out of line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't care for frauds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no fraud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever  pleases you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge, nobody forced you to come  along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm here of my own free will,  all right. We each do the master's  bidding in our own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he told you I needed  wetnursing, why don't you just turn  yourself around and go back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge snorts and fusses with his pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home, is it? You've seen to that,  haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances over and discovers Galen missing.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pret soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes  through some shrubbery.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST POOL
dialogues.text: Under the oaks and hickory, a forest stream has widened i a quiet pool. A pile of clothes lies on a rock at the edg Out in the middle, Valerian is treading water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too far behind us. Come on  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I'll catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a good idea to get separated.  Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I'll be along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen leans over and splashes some water on his face. Fee good. He shucks his pack and starts to throw off his clot Valerian doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. Don't come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Galen is now naked and walking into the water. He swi out toward Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (edgy) You better get back to the group,  they're probably worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen keeps swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer to swim alone, if you don't  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Galen has slipped beneath the surface; he doesn't hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen works his way through the murky green underwater wo Suddenly, he stops short and stares. He's only a few feet from Valerian's dangling legs. He gasps in surprise. Vale is no boy.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE
dialogues.text: Galen comes shooting to the surface, coughing and sputter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the gods!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerian is pale and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She propels herself backward, then turns and swims for sh

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SHORE
dialogues.text: Galen and Valerian have taken refuge behind separate bush Briskly they pull on their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go  ahead, I don't care. It's a relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you. I was stupid.  Careless. A silly woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeble bluff) Take it easy. I knew the moment I  saw you. I've known the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never knew a thing. No one knew.  Not since I was born. Go on, run off  and tell them. It'll make a great  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. No one's going to find  out. Just tell me: why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish dressing in silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lottery! Daughters are chosen,  but sons are not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Unless you have plenty  of gold or property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're rich enough, your name  never goes in. (bitter) My father is poor. So are a lot of  fathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies her. She jams a hat down over her head and, on more the young man, stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: THE VISION
dialogues.text: Galen walks down to the edge of the pool to retrieve his  pack. As he leans over he catches sight of what appears t be a reflection in the water: Tyrian on horseback. He whi around, but no one is behind him. Riveted by the vision, hurries along the bank to follow it. After a few paces th blurry figure dismounts, unslings a longbow, nocks an arr and draws the string taut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) No!

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: Galen sprints through the trees. Up ahead is Valerian, wa resolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances back at him and grimly keeps on walking. Gale shoots past her and on into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge!

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELERS
dialogues.text: Galen races up the trail rounds a bend and sees the Urlan coming toward him. Hodge precedes the group with an unste gait. He sees Galen, raises up his arms and flops face do on the trail. A long arrow protrudes from his back. Galen kneels beside him. The uneasy company keeps its distance. Hodge struggles to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen? Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, somebody shot me, but I  can still talk. There's something  that has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes.  Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge's hand comes out from under his coat gripping the  leather pouch. Galen tugs at it, but Hodge can't let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel  it loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen pries the sack out of Hodge's clenched fingers. Sud the hand comes up, grabs Galen by the hair, and pulls him near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a croak) ...burning water... find the lake,  throw it in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the pouch) What are you doing with this, Hodge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...burning water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dies. Galen frees himself from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hodge, don't die. Listen to me. You're  not going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen is frantic. He pulls out the amulet and wraps his h around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam! (he shakes the body) Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hodge has passed on, and Galen's magic has no way to  reach him. Suddenly the youth cries out in pain. He drops the amulet and looks at his palm. The device has burned h flesh. Now he becomes aware of troubled Urlanders looking over his shoulder, witness to his failure.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: Wind whips the leaden wave tops on a vast rainy lake. The travelers are rowing across in an open longboat, aided by tattered lateen sail. Valerian mans the steering oar at t stern while Galen broods in the bow. He feels like an imp in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FJORD
dialogues.text: The boat pulls into a long narrow waterway with granite c on either side. Moving through swirls of fog, they beach boat and step out onto a craggy shore. Greil leans over a kisses a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urland!

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The travelers descend a mountain pass and emerge through wrack of cloud into a gray and cheerless region. Fire- blackened trees dot the barren landscape. As they reach t flatlands, the Urlanders instinctively pick up the pace.  Galen slows to inspect the weird surroundings. Valerian t past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Don't dawdle here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen falls into step with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole kingdom like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're near the lair. Keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen looks around with new interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in  no danger if we just pass through  quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen stops. High on the slope beside them is a gaping  fissure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see it. Let's have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Galen is already toiling up the incline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greil! Malkin! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The travelers turn to see what's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAIR
dialogues.text: Galen approaches the lair, pausing beside a wooden post w iron manacles dangling from it. He fingers them thoughtfu Malkin, Greil and Valerian rush up behind him, their face drawn with worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you don't have to do this. We  know you're a fine young magician.  None better. There's no need to prove  it to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there other entrances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. One's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. The road's this way. We'll  tell everybody how close you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) No smoke. How do you know it's in  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool. Come away now and  live to tell about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead, Galen starts into the crack. Greil and Malkin ha away, but Valerian lingers, watching in mounting frustrat as Galen probes further and further into the lair. She pi up a fistful of stones and throws them at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead! You're going to die! What  a fine trick that will be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Galen is lost in the gloom. She flees.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERGROUND
dialogues.text: Galen puts his hand on the rugged wall: the rocks are hot the touch. Something glinting on the floor catches Galen' eye: an irridescent disk, a dragon scale. It flashes the  colors of the rainbow as Galen examines it. All at once t ground shudders; chunks of rock fall from the ceiling. A  pall of smoke billows up from the depths.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Galen staggers out of the fissure coughing and gagging in swirl of smoke. There is no sign of the Urlanders. He thr down his pack, climbs onto a huge boulder and surveys the massive cliffs rising behind the lair. He grasps the amul and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, great mountain, hear my command:  Terrae lapsus consignet latibulum  draconis! Evanescat latibulum  draconis!

dialogues.speaker: LANDSLIDE
dialogues.text: With a thunderous splitting sound, the entire top of the  cliff pitches forward and topples onto the lower half of mountain, sweeping tons of debris into the air. Boulders size of houses bound down the mountain toward the magicia Eyes wide with awe, he turns and runs for his life. Even he careens down the slope, chunks of rock rumble past. On catches him at the knee and sends him flying. He covers his head and joins the landslide. Finally the d lifts and he finds himself in a gully face to face with t cowering Urlanders. They look with real fear at the man w just conjured up the Apocalypse. Tattered and torn, cover with dirt, Galen climbs up out of the shelter for a look his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: The territory has been drastically transformed: the drago lair is now buried beneath hundreds of tons of broken gra The Urlanders look upon the new landscape with stupefacti Galen grins a triumphant split-lip grin that fails to win them over. Presently they back away and run off down the  trail, Valerian in their midst. Galen's grin fades.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE
dialogues.text: The Village of Swanscombe is little more than a rough and ready collection of thatched huts and mud-daubed outbuild surrounded by cultivated fields. Dogs sleep in open door- ways; chickens peck around the communal well -- but there are no people in evidence as Valerian and her company tro into town.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: She trots across the square and enters a deserted blacksm shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to the forge. Hot coals are burning. She be aware of a sound -- voices -- chanting.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: She walks across the square toward the voices. She is joi by Greil, Malkin and the other travelers, all of them puz by the desolation. As they approach the grange hall the v grow louder. They seem to be singing. The main doors open briefly and three villagers scamper out, dripping wet and wrapped in white muslin. Valerian and her companions look each other in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GRANGE HALL
dialogues.text: In a wooden cistern in the middle of the hall a woman is  being held under water. After a few moments she is pulled the surface by a tall red-haired man with long bony finge Brother Jacopus Januensis, a Carthusian monk. There's a w cross on his chest and a mad look in his eye. Gathered ar him are the missing villagers, every man woman and child, here to be baptised and sing a few newly-learned hymns in praise of Our Lord Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now are you cleansed of your sins!  Now are you born again, purified in  spirit, into the fellowship of Jesus  Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The travelers enter and mingle with the congregation. Val scans the crowd until she locates her father, Simon, a ba sturdy journeyman. He's overjoyed at her return and gives her a hearty embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back, my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, what are you doing? Have you  all lost your minds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the monk, who is dunking a screaming infant carrying on about the Bishop of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's this monk. He can read and write,  and talk too, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they listen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! They think this a holy place, a  tabernacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the granary. What kind of  welcome is this? I've got news of  the sorcerer and news of the dragon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were brave to go, you and your  friends. But nobody cares. Listen --  he knows what they want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Brother Jacopus strides back and forth before the assembl in an inspired state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who walks with Christ is not  a man to fear a dragon: Yea, though  I walk through the valley of the  shadow of death I will fear no evil!  You say you are preyed upon by a  foul beast. Yes, but what is the  nature of this beast? It comes to  you on bat's wings and clawed feet,  does it not? It breathes fire, does  it not? And it lives under ground.  This is no dragon. This is Lucifer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever it is, he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Galen, who has just stepped into the hall, tatter bedraggled and triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, brother! It is not as easy as  that. Allegiance to Christ, to be  sure, but also prayer and confession.  These are the arms by which Satan  may be put down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about superstition,  friend. None of that has anything to  do with what I, Galen, have already  achieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He marches to the center of the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Valerian) You brought this stranger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulrich's apprentice. He's a braggart,  but it doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People of Urland! Send a messenger  to the king. Vermithrax is dead.  Crushed by the power of the moon and  the stars! Laid low by ancient wisdom.  Dropped into the Abyss by mystical  practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoken like a pagan. Every word as  reprobate as it is false! (holding up his cross) Solum in hoc signo vinces!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nihil plus mysterium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures boldly and a fireball crackles at the monk's  feet. The holy man scurries back. A hush falls upon the  congregation.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: A procession of curious villagers winds its way into the  badlands. They gather on a promontory overlooking the dra lair. They stand there for a long time, a chill wind whip their garments, trying to understand what's happened. The monk is mightily displeased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise God! Blessed is he that is  humble before the Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your god had nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Galen's act is already the stuff of legend:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw it with our own eyes. He flew  to the mountain top. He was a bird.  He brought forth lightning. I saw  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the younger villagers scamper forward to the spot where the cave had its opening. With yells and whoops the beat the ground with clubs. In the crowd Simon begins to  smile, then to laugh. Soon he leads the villagers in a  tumultuous cheer. Brother Jacopus and some of his convert drop to their knees and pray.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: The inhabitants of Swanscombe have decked out the town sq and are making a night of it. By torchlight they dance me to jigs and reels provided by the local fiddlers. Ale flo freely from oak casks.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Valerian is kneeling before a trunk full of women's cloth She pulls out a long simple frock, goes to a crude mirror and holds it up against her body to gauge the effect. Her father comes up behind her. He is angry and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that away. What if you were seen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be seen. I want to be  seen. Tonight the world finds out  that you never had a son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you mustn't do that. It's too  soon. We've got to think about this,  we've got to make a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father: the danger is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the bed and puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. What am I going to say to my  friends who still mourn for their  lost girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll say you did what you had to.  This is a time for celebration --  and forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her, trying to imagine what it's going to like having a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: Galen is surrounded by a crowd of wide-eyed kids and not few adults, entertaining them by pulling duck's eggs out their ears and causing coins to disappear. Presently he f the attention of his audience shift away to someone stand behind him. He turns to find a shy but determined Valeria sweetly decked out in her blue frock. A buzz goes through the crowd. Valerian blushes and wavers: she seems ready t bolt for home. But Galen takes her by the hand, and with  conspicuous politesse leads her to the dance.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: It's forward, back and around sixth-century style: the yo sorcerer can't take his eyes off his partner. But she's t shy to return his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you've been up to a little  sorcery yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerian doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is it witchcraft?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still doesn't reply. It's all she can do to keep on  dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? A real woman never  stops talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was much easier being a  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMON & GREIL They stand on the sidelines, watching the young couple st to the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The damnedest thing is, she was twice  the man of anyone else in the village.  Now she's twice the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) Would that I had been as clever as  her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a  life spared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begrudge nothing. But I wonder at  what we have seen and how it was  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw what I saw. But this jack-anapes  was barely ready to carry his master's  chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at  the very moment the beast is put  down we should have a holy man here  in the village?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe that superstitious  Christian rot, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) It is said God works his wonders in  mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: While the proud Simon dances in the background with his  daughter, a group of tipsy villagers clusters around Gale belching forth a drinking song. The young magician raises his own mug and joins in on the chorus. Abruptly the musi stops. The singing dies away. The ensuing silence is brok by the sound of galloping hooves. Presently three horseme appear at the end of town: Tyrian and his henchmen. They  guide their horses forward into the midst of the merry-ma Tyrian dismounts and looks around in his usual friendly w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A celebration! Don't stop on my  account. You -- musicians, more music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musicians leave their instruments in their laps. Tyri draws himself a measure of ale and raises it above his he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast! To the deed of the day! You  see, good news travels fast. The  King himself has already heard it.  And like yourselves, tonight he's  overcome with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you have of us then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing. It's this one. (he gestures toward  Galen) The King would meet our new benefactor  and offer his gratitude to the man  who succeeded where so many have  failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobering up) What sort of gratitude? A knife in  the belly? An arrow in the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian's smile freezes on his face. He steps in front of  Galen, towering over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My young friend, I'd as soon dispatch  you as I did the others, and for the  same reason. But his Majesty would  like a cozy chat, and commands  otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go, Galen. Cast a spell and  turn them into toads. It should be  easy; that's what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian regards her coolly, taking in her change of costum and its meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well: still plenty of cheek  under those skirts, it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having buried the dragon under a mountain, Galen decides  he's not worried about an appearance at court. He smiles Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: RIDERS
dialogues.text: Three horses gallop through the moors and fens of central Urland. Galen is tucked up behind Tyrian. On the distant  horizon, the battlements of the King's castle glow in the slanting light of a new day.

dialogues.speaker: THRONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Within the castle is a great hall with shafts of daylight poking in through narrow windows set high in the walls. I the middle of the room stands a carved oak throne. There Casiodorus Rex, King of Urland, a bearded man in his fift as spare and somber as the room in which he sits. He is  flanked by a few servants, assorted courtiers and Tyrian. Standing before them all is Galen, looking unhappy. He po a pitcher full of water into a small glazed goblet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the best things about the  water here in Urland is that there's  so much of it -- look at that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water continues to pour into the goblet without overflowi Galen takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. Good. But not cold enough.  Perhaps I could borrow a scarf from  his Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King makes no sign. Galen approaches stiffly, takes a scarf and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cover the goblet, so... remove,  so... and behold: winter in a mug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's done it: he turns the goblet over and a small ch of ice hits the floor. The royal reaction is equally fros Galen is bombing, and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. How many of you have ever  seen a table fly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mutters an incantation. In the audience, Tyrian notes  that Galen has his hand wrapped around the amulet. There a loud clatter as the heavy oak table before the throne b to jitter and buck. As the wine spills and plates go flyi the King wearily raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough! That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, it'll rise now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother. Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table cracks in half and dumps a mess of fruit and  crockery at the onlookers' feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me: the landslide -- it was  accomplished this same way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And having rendered such unique  service to our kingdom, what would  you claim as a reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- no payment. I have always  found magical practice to be its own  reward. I seek only some yet greater  challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This handsome sentiment doesn't go over any better than h tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric?  Of course not, you weren't even born.  He was my brother, a great King and  a valiant man-at-arms. When he  ascended to the throne, the dragon  was unbridled. No one knew where it  might strike next. So he brought  forth his broadsword and his spear,  assembled a company of his best  fighters and went out to do battle. (pause) He was never seen again. But his  attack provoked the most terrible  reprisals: whole villages incinerated,  entire crops burned. Death, famine,  horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King grimaces as the memories come flooding back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) How did you arrogate to yourself the  role of savior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by me. Did you ever consider the  consequences of failure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What failure? What's the matter with  you people? You want the dragon back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the beast is dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall see.

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: Two guards thrust Galen into a narrow cell and slam the b door shut. The young sorcerer waits until they're safely of sight, then takes out his amulet. He ponders it for a  doubtful moment. Suddenly a gloved hand darts in and whip it off his neck and out through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes an ironic salute and leaves. Galen sits down hea and stares at the stone walls.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Unseen by Galen, a figure clad in silk and lace skitters  down a murky dungeon hallway and peers around a corner.  Stealing a look at Galen is the Princess Elspeth, a fey b in her early twenties. After a moment, spooked by some  imagined noise, she flits away.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: Dark clouds slide across a pale sun, throwing the ruined  land below into shadow. Soon fat droplets of rain are  splattering on the rocks above the dragon's lair. With ea tiny splash there is a sizzle and a puff of steam. These  rocks are hot!

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: Outside the barred window, a steady rain is falling. Insi Galen uses a chunk of limestone to inscribe a pentagram o the floor of his cell. He marks runic signs on the window sill and lintel. Then, positioning himself in the center the mystic symbol, he raises his hands and spreads his  fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (authoritative) Cubiculum gravis aperat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long moment when nothing happens. A very long  moment. Finally, a thoroughly frustrated Galen leaps to t window and rattles the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up, dammit! Fenestra gravis  aperat! Asser gravis aperat!  Divinitus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salve, magistrum iuvenilum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, Galen whirls around to find Elspeth standing ou his cell. She hands some food and blankets through the ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me  appelo Elspeth, filia regis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen looks her over. He's never seen anyone so angelic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't think ill of us. My  father is a wonderful man, a wise  man. The lottery was his idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. From the moment  it began, the dragon was tame. The  kingdom prospered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And only a few had to be sacrificed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true. Isn't it better  that a few should die that many might  live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on who does the dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but we all take our chances. My  father is a just man. My name is  entered on the lists, along with  every other young --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maiden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've participated in every drawing  since I came of age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. You don't believe me. You  think I'm lying. Well I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I heard a rumor. Families  with money, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to rumors. They're lies.  I have to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- how long do I have to stay  in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until we know. Not long. Goodbye.  Vale. Dormi bene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slips away down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: King Casiodorus and Tyrian are huddled over a table piled high with manuscripts and papers. Tyrian clears a spot an sets out a stack of lead bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough. Let's not be greedy  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King picks up Galen's amulet, and holds it over the b in his clenched fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then: I, Casiodorus Rex do hereby  command thou base metal to change  thy essence and become gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a rustle of skirts and Elspeth appears behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one  bar. We'll try it one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father: did you know that some  families have paid bribes to stay  out of the lottery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King and Tyrian glance up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. By the power of this amulet,  justly wielded by my hand in  accordance with the laws of Urland,  now lead be thou gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lead remains unchanged, but the King gives out a cry drops the amulet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm burned! What devilish thing is  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever kept my name off the  lottery list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be all, Tyrian. You may  withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian bows and exits. The King uses his sceptre to pick the amulet and chain. He conceals it in a hollowed-out bo and places the volume on a shelf among many others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my dear, what's troubling you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer my question: am I not exposed  to the same risk as every other man's  daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King paces over to the window and stares out. The rai has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Your father loves you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elspeth sways in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wail) It's true! What have you done to  me!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who fills your head with such ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment a tremor passes through the room. King and daughter look at each other in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: The same tremor shakes the bars in Galen's cell. Puzzled, rolls off his straw palette and gets to his feet. The tre dies away. Suddenly a violent shaking hits the cell, boun Galen off the walls.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE SQUARE
dialogues.text: Swanscombe is gripped by the same earthquake. Dodging pan barnyard animals, Valerian and her father join other  frightened villagers in the center of town.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: Above the dragon's lair, boulders are shifting and grindi together. Massive chunks of stone break loose and tumble  down the incline.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: The shaking has stopped. Rock dust filters down from the  ceiling. Galen picks himself up and stares: the door to h cell is off its hinges and is sagging open. He darts out.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Galen dashes along the hallway, rounds a corner and stops At the other end of the passage is Tyrian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little meddler! It's alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws his sword and advances. Galen warily retreats. T breaks into a run. Galen turns and sprints away.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Unruly horses, terrified by the quake, rush blindly aroun the courtyard. Hostlers try vainly to catch them. Tyrian  leans down from an upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the main gate! Quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men below scramble for the gates. Galen bursts out of hiding, sees the untended horses, and swings aboard as on goes past. A cry goes up from the guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There! Stop him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen rides like mad for the exit, but he's a half-second late: the doors boom shut in his face. He wheels the hors around. The King's men are coming toward him with pikes.  Digging his heels into the horse's sides, he urges the an back across the courtyard, up the steps and right into th building!

dialogues.speaker: THRONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen gallops into the empty chamber, knocking over the t and vaulting a table. Hot on his heels are armed soldiers He kicks the horse again and shoots under an archway.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: The kitchen is already in chaos from the earthquake when  Galen charges in on his wild steed. Food, utensils and co go flying. He reins in, ducks his head, and squeezes the  horse out into a narrow hallway.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: He clatters down the passageway. But here comes a conting of footmen from the opposite direction. Galen rides them  into the walls!

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: The horse scrabbles up the stairs, Galen tucked low again its neck. On the upper landing he comes face to face with Tyrian and more soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him! Stab the horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen jerks the animal around and plunges back down the  stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Whinnying and blowing the horse bursts in, a wild-eyed Ga still in the saddle. He finds himself confronting the Kin and his daughter. Casiodorus grabs Elspeth and retreats into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian! Tyrian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrian sweeps in with his men. The doors slam shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for your magic! So much for  your sorcery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen is trapped. Just as Tyrian reaches for the horse's  reins, the animal rears up, rolling its eyes. At that mom the floor heaves and cracks in a new series of shocks. Th men at arms go down like ten pins. Tyrian reels back, dod stone blocks loosened from the ceiling. As the shaking  continues, a weakened section of wall gives way. Galen se daylight! Without even waiting for the quake to cease, he prods the horse across the room and through the wall to  freedom.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The unnerved citizens of Swanscombe gather on the promont overlooking Galen's landslide. Every few seconds there is new shudder and more rocks pour down the long slope. Vale stands trembling with her father. Presently Brother Jacop elbows his way forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, my brethren. The moment  of our fear is the moment of our  triumph. This is a sign from God.  Follow me, and our faith will send  this creature straight to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding a cross before him, he starts up the slope. No on follows. They haven't been Christians all that long. One two near Valerian get down on their knees and pray silent Greil looks things over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call yourselves Christians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides after the monk. But he's the only one.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE LAIR
dialogues.text: The determined monk has arrived at the epicenter. His san are smoking on the hot gravel. Sweat shines on his face a neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not  want. Thou makest me to lie down in  green pastures. Thy rod and staff  they comfort me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greil toils up the slope a hundred yards back. He's cross himself, but he's carrying a sickle.

dialogues.speaker: VERMITHRAX
dialogues.text: There is a thunderous noise. Part of the mountain is toss into the air. Up from the depths comes a huge shining win Then a neck uncoils and a head appears. It tips down towa the tiny human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm) ...for Thine is the kingdom and the  power and the glory forever -- amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the base of the slope the villagers scatter. Greil wav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unclean beast, get thee down! Be  thou consumed by the fires that made  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
